content:
Astor Piazzolla’s “tango operita” ought to be a regular part of the music-theatre repertory by now. It has all the ingredients of a popular stage show, and CD recordings of it run into double figures, but in Britain at least, María de Buenos Aires has yet to be presented convincingly on stage. This recording, from the Bonn Opera, appears to have been taken from a concert performance, too. If the work really is dramatically intractable, then the problem is partly the work itself. Horacio Ferrer’s libretto has holes, and it’s written in lunfardo, a working-class dialect developed in the River Plate area of Argentina and Uruguay in the 19th century. Attempts to turn it into “proper” Spanish, or English, sanitise the text and rid it of the earthiness that’s an essential part of its world.

For Piazzolla and Ferrer intended the story of María, the girl born in a poor district of Buenos Aires who becomes a famous nightclub singer but is eventually destroyed by the criminal underworld and then haunts the city as a ghost, to be the story of tango itself and its rebirth as tango nuevo in the hands of composers such as Piazzolla. María de Buenos Aires is effectively a number opera – combining classical forms such as fugue, melodrama and toccata with tangos and Argentinian folk tunes – but it is a number opera of a strikingly original kind.
The performance, conducted by Christopher Sprenger, doesn’t always get that balance between classical propriety and tango roughness right. The strings of the Bonn Beethoven Orchestra give the sound a rather glutinous veneer, and the bandoneon-led chamber group accompanying many of the solo numbers isn’t quite edgy enough. But as María, Luciana Mancini gets just the right edge of stridency into her voice, and in the spoken role of El Duende, Daniel Bonilla-Torres delivers his narrations with nice detachment. Yet what’s always missing is the sense of rawness and danger that Piazzolla’s own recordings brought to his music.
Also out this week
A concert performance of Manuel de Falla’s La Vida Breve last year was part of Juanjo Mena’s final season as principal conductor of the BBC Philharmonic, and the new Chandos recording, with Nancy Fabiola Herrera as the Gypsy Salud, was made in Manchester a few days later. Though vividly played and recorded, it’s a rather staid performance of a work that’s a potent mix of Debussyan impressionism and Italian verismo. Mena’s account misses the exciting extremes of the best versions on record, both now admittedly rather elderly – there’s none of the bleakness of Frühbeck de Burgos’s account, with Victoria de Los Angeles as Salud, or the dramatic fierceness of García Navarro’s, with Teresa Berganza.
